required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Treatment of Candidal Vulvovaginitis Using Cumin Seed Extract Vaginal Suppositories.
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Clinical Trial for Treatment of Candidal Vulvovaginitis Using Cumin Seed Extract Vaginal Suppositories.

brief_summary.textblock: Fungal infections have increased over the last two decades, largely because of the increasing size of the population at risk, including patients who are immunocompromised, broad-spectrum antibiotics and intravascular catheter users. Essential oils and other extracts of plants have evoked interest as sources of natural products. They have been shown to possess antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral, insecticidal and antioxidant properties. To the best of our knowledge, no study has examined the efficacy of cumin seed extract on relieving vulvovaginal candidiasis in vivo.

primary_outcome.measure: The percentage of patients with complete cure
primary_outcome.description: cure is defines as absence of symptoms

arm_group.description: Group A (study group) will receive Cumin seed extract vaginal suppositories once daily for 7 days.
Group B will receive conventional clotrimazole vaginal suppositories once daily for 7 days.

intervention.description: patients will receive the drug in suppository form
patients will receive the drug in suppository form
